name: NPR
text:
As a "social circus," Zip Zap aims to foster personal development and positive social change. It's become world-famous along the way — entertaining everyone from Roger Federer to Obama.

"Respect — that's what I've learnt from Zip Zap," says one performer.
https://t.co/wdEzoSfywt

name: NPR
text: With Biden leading in the polls, Democrats are haunted by the ghosts of 2016 when Hillary Clinton led, too. But there are a few key factors that make this year's election different, writes @DomenicoNPR. https://t.co/vJHxyxWuBB

name: NPR
text:
The title of Nate Marshall's new book comes from the phrase "fixing to." It's "all about what happens next. It's this thing that is informed by history, but that is all about looking forward, all about possibility."

"That's sort of what I hope poems do." https://t.co/v7SOYCaiK7

name: NPR
text: Nebraska expects to have only about $50 million less to spend than projected before the pandemic, nowhere near the kind of dropoff seen in other states. @NETNewsNebraska https://t.co/L9zstNOgLT

name: NPR
text: West Virginia's governor has faced criticism for how he decided to use some of his state's $1.25 billion from the federal CARES Act, meant for states to cover coronavirus-related expenses. @wvpublic https://t.co/NjNaIPXkCA

name: NPR
text:
Farms have already reported coronavirus outbreaks among hundreds of workers. 

And yet, the federal government hasn't established any enforceable rules to protect farmworkers from the virus or instruct farms what to do when they get sick. 
https://t.co/Zzv7JJ7iUk

name: NPR
text: New York and Connecticut are launching investigations into utility companies as millions remain without power a day after Tropical Storm Isaias tore through the Northeast. https://t.co/NTmV4MMxOq

name: NPR
text:
Tim Minchin's friend came up with the premise for his new series, "Upright." 

"He wanted to create a comedy show with me in it that involved a guy trying to get across Australia with a piano on the back of a ute," he says. 
https://t.co/tJVhHhhHap

name: NPR
text: Since many of us know Bryan Cranston from Breaking Bad, @waitwait invited him to play a game called "Braking ... good!" — 3 questions about safe driving. https://t.co/v1zBplRIqf

name: NPR
text:
New York's 14-day quarantine requirement for travelers from high-risk states is legally binding. But authorities can't force people to register for follow-up — leaving it largely dependent on goodwill and voluntary compliance.
https://t.co/kkizWeC21T

name: NPR
text:
An author explores her sister's death under mysterious circumstances in a hotel in Mexico — offering more plot twists, shocking revelations and shady characters than most contemporary thrillers, our reviewer says.
https://t.co/halpFnsldu

name: NPR
text:
For more than a century, food has been getting more abundant — and cheaper. And yet people keep worrying about shortages. 

Some economists say the fears actually create their own problems.
https://t.co/CnjADWZWbS

name: NPR
text: Duval County has been a reliable Republican vote for over four decades. But Democrats are sensing new optimism ahead of the election, thanks to intense anti-Trump energy among black voters, young voters and college-educated professionals in the suburbs. https://t.co/U9QhbwOIJC

name: NPR
text: It's difficult to eradicate a virus completely, and COVID-19 isn't any different. The disease might never go away, but it doesn't mean that everyone will have to self-isolate forever. https://t.co/fnRagqJtq3

name: NPR
text: With theaters and movies on hold during the pandemic, it can feel like there's not much else to do but binge on TV. We ask reporters in eight countries to tell us what TV shows people have been obsessed about. https://t.co/Whdz5bIx2M

name: NPR
text: Stay-at-home orders and business closures in Illinois blew a big hole in the state budget. The state will need to borrow $5 billion from the Federal Reserve next year. @WBEZ https://t.co/qE0ZBoxiET

name: NPR
text:
Alexis Daria's "You Had Me at Hola" had me at Latinx representation, sexy soapy plot, and a meta-telenovela addicting enough to actually get picked up by Netflix IRL, our reviewer writes.
https://t.co/1mvEDUozCW

name: NPR
text: Colorado state lawmakers had to slash about a quarter of the budget to keep state finances in the black. Of the $3.3 billion cut, education and health care were hit especially hard. @COPublicRadio https://t.co/Rqcg6M8X0h

name: NPR
text:
Delta has banned 100 anti-maskers from taking their flights — and even gone a step further by adding them to a "no fly" list.

Despite outrage from some consumers, legal experts say it's within the airline's scope of rights. 
https://t.co/c0dtsj6fgn

name: NPR
text: RT @hansilowang: NEW: After cutting short #2020Census counting time, the Census Bureau is offering "award pay" of up to $800 to try to encourage door knockers to work more hours this month while completing at least .75 cases/hour, according to a Aug. 8 email sent to workers that I've obtained. https://t.co/ET2qS5i62dNEW: After cutting short #2020Census counting time, the Census Bureau is offering "award pay" of up to $800 to try… https://t.co/NQrTBqKHfK

name: NPR
text:
In Missouri, Republican Gov. Mike Parson withheld hundreds of millions of dollars from the 2021 fiscal year budget — which began on July 1 because of declining revenues. 

Among those impacted: universities, colleges, and K-12 schools. @stlpublicradio https://t.co/UrqViZbrKj

name: NPR
text: In New York, Democratic Gov. Cuomo has threatened to cut money to schools, local governments & hospitals by as much as 20% — in as soon as a couple of weeks — if Congress doesn't agree on relief that includes direct aid to state and local governments. https://t.co/SpGPMiWw3m

name: NPR
text:
Ohio has closed their budget gap, in part, by cutting more than $775 million in spending for the fiscal year that ended June 30. 

Higher ed, K-12 schools & Medicaid — which take up the largest portion of the overall state budget — saw the biggest cuts. https://t.co/EEGD7gTlv8

name: NPR
text: Oklahoma's budget booms and busts with the energy sector. And with oil prices plummeting amid the coronavirus crisis, the state budget is in shambles. @KOSURadio https://t.co/Mq1ipmc7BD

name: NPR
text: The bad news: tax revenue in Oregon from March to May was down 53% compared to 2019. The good news? The state has record reserves on hand to — somewhat — paper over the losses. @OPB https://t.co/3R9cexaIZe

name: NPR
text:
Pennsylvania passed a 5-month budget plan in May.

When it runs out, state lawmakers expect to face tough decisions, including how to fund programs that benefit people with intellectual disabilities, nursing home residents & victims of domestic violence. https://t.co/kT6d8MXvVx

name: NPR
text:
A new CDC analysis of children hospitalized for the coronavirus finds:

• 1 in 3 was admitted to the ICU 
• Black kids were 5 times as likely as white kids to be hospitalized
• Hispanic kids were about 8 times as likely as white kids to be hospitalized https://t.co/TmYKZpnS80

name: NPR
text: Annual budget deficits are as common in Rhode Island as the quahogs in Narragansett Bay, but the pandemic has made the usual red ink far more prevalent. @ThePublicsRadio https://t.co/muOGY9B9cA

name: NPR
text: South Carolina's exceptionally strong economy over the last two fiscal years has allowed the state to weather the pandemic with little budget disruptions to date. @SCPublicRadio https://t.co/xC5Drxijry

name: NPR
text: South Dakota expects a nearly $40 million decrease in anticipated revenue for the fiscal year that goes through June 30, 2021, because of the pandemic. @SDPBNews https://t.co/vstzLOECJ7

name: NPR
text: Tennessee Lt. Gov. Randy McNally: "Probably in the 42 some odd years that I've been in the legislature, this is the worst budget crisis that we've faced." @WPLN https://t.co/KEJTckcPvL

name: NPR
text:
Texas state revenues have taken a serious beating since the beginning of the pandemic. 

The crash in oil prices sent oil production tax receipts down a whopping 77% June 2020 — compared with last June — with natural gas production receipts down 84%. https://t.co/ZAUCIex13c

name: NPR
text: The U.S. hit 5 million confirmed coronavirus cases on Sunday — just 17 days after crossing the 4 million mark. More than 162,400 people have died, accounting for roughly 22% of global deaths from COVID-19. https://t.co/Npphxmmopr

name: NPR
text:
RT @asmamk: In a county that for more than 4 decades has been a reliable GOP vote, Democrats are sensing new optimism ahead of Nov, thanks to intense anti-Trump energy among black voters, young voters and college-educated professionals in the suburbs.

My latest 👇

https://t.co/zD19Vzr4vL

name: NPR
text:
TikTok plans to sue the Trump administration, arguing that the president's executive order banning the app from the U.S. is unconstitutional because it failed to give the company a chance to respond.
https://t.co/wPSJMoVTnp

name: NPR
text:
North Dakota's economy is dependent on oil and agriculture, but farmers are receiving less money for what they grow and oil demand has dropped. 

As a result, the state faces significant belt-tightening. @prairiepublic https://t.co/DCEXk34Js0

name: NPR
text:
Musée Rodin in Paris is selling sculptures to pay the bills — and that's what the artist wanted. When he died in 1917, Rodin left the museum the original plaster molds of more than 100 sculptures just for this purpose.
 https://t.co/CNUC6UgrFg

name: NPR
text: Neil Young has filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against the Trump campaign, saying it doesn’t have the rights to play his songs "Rockin' in the Free World" and "Devil's Sidewalk" at rallies and events. https://t.co/iYd3lazraJ

name: NPR
text:
A national poll of teachers finds overwhelming trepidation about returning to the physical classroom:

• 82% are concerned about returning to in-person teaching
• two-thirds prefer to teach primarily remote
• 77% are worried about risking their health
https://t.co/sJYWzmYJ4H

name: NPR
text:
Some lawmakers and experts are voicing concerns about the president's moves to control federal spending, which is a power reserved for Congress.
https://t.co/uYqRc56zA5
